Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the situation by stating that Phil Murphy is only allowing in-person voting on Election Day at Prudential Center in Newark, when in fact, mail-in ballots will be sent to all registered voters and other polling locations will be available.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the decision to use Prudential Center as a super polling site is solely made by Phil Murphy, without considering the role of individual counties in choosing final polling sites.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support to prove that Phil Murphy is intentionally limiting in-person voting options to only Prudential Center. The information provided suggests that the decision is part of a broader plan to provide accessibility and options for voters.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the decision to use Prudential Center as a super polling site, such as the need to consolidate voting districts or logistical considerations.
Understate: The claim may understate the availability of other in-person polling locations on Election Day by suggesting that Prudential Center is the only option, while the information provided states that counties are required to provide at least half their usual polling locations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that mail-in ballots will be sent to all registered voters in the general election, suggesting that only in-person voting will be allowed at Prudential Center.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a comprehensive and accurate representation of the voting options available and the decision-making process for choosing polling locations.
